subject: Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... Thus the QM needs augmentation to clarify non BBC pronunciation. ... functions ... Sounds like a nice idea. How would you write the definition of Et such
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> Anthony Grahn scripsit:
>
> > Perhaps more important is preventing me from writing Tea-Awe-Tea for
> > "tot" while Tea-Ox-Tea for "taught" which reading the QM with no
> > outside material would let me do.
>
> Well, there you are. Despite apparent concessions, QS was designed
> around the RP accent (as TO was designed around an earlier version
> of the London accent).

Thus the QM needs augmentation to clarify non BBC pronunciation.



> But we don't have to put up with "iksent" or "ayksunt" for "accent"
> (instead of "aksent"), if we accept the principle that Et is used for
> whatever sound functions in the writer's dialect the way short-e
functions
> in "mainstream" dialects.

Sounds like a nice idea. How would you write the definition of Et
such that beginners in all accents understand it?



> > That reading text with varied spelling is a bit slower is not the
> > end of the world. Elizabethan England functioned adequately I think.
>
> In a totally different situation: many fewer people, a much lower
> literacy rate overall, less emphasis on reading and writing in daily
> life generally, and relentlessly ignoring all dialects except London's
> (and maybe 40-50 miles around it). Most Elizabethan spelling variation
> is random, not used to reflect people's dialects: Shakespeare, as is
well
> known, spelled his name in 16 different ways, none of them
"Shakespeare".

If Elizabethan England functioned adequately with random spelling
(QS is orderly within an accent) and lower literacy (QS users are a
priori literate) then QS will function at least as well. And indeed,
the Elizabethan lunatic orthodoxy produced a Shakespeare as you point out.


>
> > And the bulk of a person's communication is normally done with people
> > of his own accent in which case there would be no variation.
>
> I doubt that. In my household of four persons, there are five dialects
> in use, as my daughter is nicely bi-dialectal. In any case, most of
> our *written* communication is likely to be with people with different
> dialects.
>

I believe that constitutes an anecdote, not quite constituting
compelling evidence of the majority's behavior. Are you saying that
the *majority* of the *typical* person's family, friends and coworkers
are in an accent remarkably different than theirs? I must disagree.



[re:]
http://quickscript.tonygrahn.com/spellcomparison.html

> > If you compare the two you'll notice they are overwhelmingly the
> > same spelling. Yet my version uses a dictionary from Carnegie-Melon
> > university with specific American accent mappings for each QS letter
> > but the QM example uses RP English (aka BBC or Posh English). So even
> > though they are virtually identical on the written page, one version
> > is as it would be written by Queen Elizabeth and the other by David
> > Hasselhoff!
>
> Unfortunately, that's because your accent mappings for American are very
> conservative, reflecting neither the (different) mergers of Western or
> Southern or the (different) vowel shifts of the Inland North and the
> Inland South. And of course Southern Hemisphere English is a whole
> different ball-game, with an entirely different set of vowel shifts.
>

I'm afraid you are in error; you draw the conclusion circularly
merely because the two examples are spelled similarly. The American
example sounds exactly like the Bay Watch cast when read aloud.
Are you saying Pamela Anderson speaks "a rather conservative form of
English", more so even than your own (you did yourself say "...my
accent is not even vaguely RP...")

I contend that, in practice at least, anyone anywhere would
reproduce the example in the QM with a tiny number of letter changes.
If you feel our friends in the antipodes would write QS radically
differently, just point me to some downloadable Australian
pronunciation dictionary I'll run it through my app so you can prove
your point.
